CLASSICAL ARCHAEOLOGY.

In response to the request of the editors to
tell in the NEWS-LETTER something of the nature and scope of classical archaeology, I shall
attempt to state what classical archaeology is
and to define its place in the educational system. I must confess that to the general reader
archaeology sounds far away and mysterious,
altogether out of touch with modern life and
thought, but I hope to show that it belongs to
a branch of culture which we cannot afford to
neglect, and that the present vigorous prosecution of archaeological studies is a response
to the scientific spirit of the age.
In his memorable inaugural address, after
discussing the intellectual education and moral
education which the system of schools and
universities is intended to promote, John
Stuart Mill continues: "These are the two
main ingredients of human culture; but they
do not exhaust the whole of it. There is a
third division, which, if subordinate and owing
allegiance to the two others, is barely inferior
to them, and not less useful to the completeness of the human being; I mean the aesthetic
branch; the culture which comes through
poetry and art, and may be described as the
education of the feelings and the cultivation of
the beautiful."
Mill then emphasizes the place which
aesthetic culture occupies in any system of education which claims to be liberal, and shows
how the natural results of the study of the
fine arts are refinement of the taste, enlargement of the sympathies, cultivation of the
imagination and promotion of the love of
beauty.
Now as archaeology employs itself chiefly
with the study of the fine arts of antiquity,
with architecture and sculpture and painting—
it contributes largely to the aesthetic culture

No. 7

which Mill deems essential to the completeness
of the human being.
Furthermore, scientific method has demanded that the study of the ancient languages
should be brought into close connection with
the life of the peoples that spoke them. This
has created a desire for facts as to their laws
and their customs, their beliefs and their cults.
For these facts no source is so trustworthy
as the works of contemporary art, which may
be regarded as the mirror in which antique
thought is reflected. Hence the material relics
of antiquity—temples, and sculptures and
vases, the products of excavations at Athens
and Olympia and Delphi are now closely
woven into the web of classical learning. And
the science which treats this material and
makes information concerning it accessible to
every student of Greek and Roman literature
is classical archaeology.
We are now prepared to show the relation
of archaeology to classical philology, and to
define its province and departments. The reconstruction of the human past of Greece and
Rome is the grand ideal of classical philology
in its broadest sense. To accomplish this end,
it must collect, classify, and interpret the manifold record of antiquity. This record has come
down to us in the spoken language where that
is preserved, in the works of literature, and in
the monuments, i. e., in the extant remains of
architecture, sculpture and the other arts—in
fine, in all the results of human activity manifested in form and substance, as opposed to
the unsubstantial means employed in literature. This last branch comprises the subject
matter of classical archaeology and we may
define it as the scientific study of the monuments of classical antiquity which operate
through mass, form and color, according to
their peculiar modes of expression; or to put it

We present as our leading article in this
issue a brief discussion of Classical Archaeology by Dr. Mitchell Carroll. Dr. Carroll, who
was for some time a member of the American
School at Athens and derives his knowledge
of the subject at first hand, is now delivering
courses of lectures on "Greek Sculpture" and
"Antique Aesthetics." Courses on "The
Acroplis" and "The Topography of Athens"
were completed before Christmas. In this
connection many will remember the very entertaining lecture "Home Life in Pompeii,"
given last year by Professor Morgan, of Harvard. Such discussions show that archaeology
in spite of its scientific name, is a very interesting subject.
Some time ago favorable comment was
made in our columns on a proposal to revive
the dances formerly in vogue under the management of the Matriculate Society. Recently
it was announced that a series of dances had
been arranged, and the natural impression was
that they were of this character. Far from reviving the old dances, however, those now in
progress are on a plan entirely new at Hopkins. In the first place they are conducted by
a self-conStituted board of managers, and
though styled "Hopkins dances," are restrict-

ed to a limited number, whom the managers
choose to invite. In the second place, it appears that this prerogative, apparently derived
irom the authorities, has been used in an arbitrary manner. Acceptability in a certain circle
seems to be one requirement, affiliation with
certain fraternities another. The status of the
dances is thus left uncertain. The presence of
a member of the faculty on the board of managers adds to the official character implied by
the name and place. At the same time it is
privately declared that the dances are by no
means public affairs.
The result is general and well-justified
dissatisfaction among the students. The
action of the managers was unwise, and
the effect unfortunate. We question decidedly whether private dances have any
place in McCoy Hall, a building in which
we are supposed to have common rights. It
is certainly true that if such dances are held
they ought to be given by a definite organization and under a distinctive name. We can
hardly believe, however, that the authorities
contemplate granting the use of the hall for
exclusive dances given by various cliques of
students. Divisions enough exist already.
Hostility between fraternity factions and nonfraternity men has worked evil in our college
life before now, and one of the worst features
of the present affair is that it revives this feeling. When opposition of the two forces
brought about a dead-lock in the junior class
of last year, both sides recognized the harm of
it, and an amicable adjustment was reached.
Many hoped that this would continue. It
seems that the hope was vain. Perhaps still
more unfortunate, is the element of class distinction introduced by the managers.
There is no room for modern society
methods in our college life, and there is no
place where snobbishness is more undtsirable.
Opinions may differ as to the proportion of
"sheep and goats" among Hopkins students,
but we cannot feel that the undesirable element
includes a large majority of them. Certainly
if the latter class should presume to intrude in

THE NEWS-LETTER.
ATHLE,TICS.
IN-DOOR BASEBALL.

Last Saturday morning the inter-class indoor baseball schedule of games was resumed
in the cage, but the Christmas vacation has
not resulted, apparently, in any very great improvement in the playing of the teams. A beholder would not have been particularly edified at 'Saturday's game, except, possibly, in
regard to the superabundance of errors and
the wrangling over adverse decisions which
occupied the greater part of each inning. The
playing was by no means of the highest order,
except in a few cases, but the fact that the
teams did not have all of their regular men out
may have been partly responsible for this.
The indoor baseball season started in with
a loud flourish of trumpets, and the first few
games were marked by great enthusiasm and
fine team work. But the enthusiasm soon
waned, and the remaining games were postponed again and again, until they were in danger of sharing the fate common to too many
athletic enterprises at the University, which
begin their careers so brilliantly, only to glimmer and go out, and be forgotten.
The outdoor baseball season will soon be
upon us, and this indoor practice should develop material for the 'Varsity team. Our
baseball record for the past few years has not
been a particularly glorious one, and prospective candidates for this season's team should
take the utmost advantage of the opportunities
here offered. Do not let the indoor games end
in mere sport and amusement. Make them tell
in the way of practice.
Saturday's game between the Seniors and
the Freshmen resulted in a victory for the
former by a score of 9 to 5, although the
Freshmen improved toward the last and made
all their runs in the last three innings, while
the Seniors made theirs at the beginning of the
game. Downs pitched well for '99, and for
several innings he, with the assistance of the

first and third basemen, did all the work. 'Joyner made some wonderful catches at third,
stopping everything that came his way. Constantine, for the Freshmen, rivaled him in his
brilliant work at third, and was several times
applauded for his fine plays. Grimes, Hanna,
Guggenheimer, Swindell, Miller, and Briscoe
all played well.
The Freshmen were shut out up to the
seventh inning, but took a spurt then, and
made all their runs in the next few innings.
The umpiring was not the finest ever seen at
the University, and this resulted in much dispute. The players were, Seniors: Mullen,
Grimes, Downs, Joyner, Jones, Hanna, Guggenheimer, and Ford; Freshmen: Constantine, Briscoe, Miller, Straus, Tyler, Swindell,
James, Boyer, and Bruton.

THE EXHIBITION.

From time to time intimations are given out
of the elaborate plans that are being made for
the spring gymnastic exhibition. Teams representing the undergraduate classes are to
strive for a cup given annually by the UniverMr. James L. McLane, who had so
sity.
much to do with giving us the cage, offers a
gold medal for the best all-round gymnast.
Mr. William S. Hilles, A. B. '89, will provide
another for the best wrestler. The winner of
the contest in club-swinging will receive a fine
pair of clubs from Mr. E. D. Loane. A medal
provided by Professor Adams will be given to
the freshman whose strength tests show the
greatest improvement during the year. More
prizes may be added to the list before the exhibition.
If the contest for class teams is to be a success, there must be sonic faithful work in the
gym., especially by the juniors and seniors.
Compulsory gymnastics have so far failed to
compel, at least the upper classmen. It remains to be seen what effect prizes and class
spirit will have.

THE NEWS—LETTER.
THE FEED.

The Feed for this year will be held in the
cage and gymnasium Thursday evening, January 12. The exercises will be similar to those
of last year. There will be addresses by President Gilman, Professor Remsen, and Mr. William Hilles. The stunt games in the cage will
include several new features and some old
ones that have proved amusing. There will be
a greased pole to climb, sack and obstruction
races, "chicken-fights," boxing with blackened
gloves, and other things of like nature. Refreshments, the feature from which the function derived its name will follow. Mr. Robert
H. Grimes will be master of ceremonies and
Mr. William H. Mackdermott, clerk of the
course. Plans for the evening have been made
by a general committee, of which Mr. Grimes
is chairman and Mr. George W. Knapp, Jr.,
treasurer. The invitation to attend includes all
members of the University from "sub-fresh"
to faculty and all should be present.
THE B. A. C. (JAMES.

The lethargy in athletics, resulting from the
occupation of everyone's mind with examinations and the sterner things of life, is now at an
end, and steps are being taken toward the resumption of sports at the University.
The next event of interest to our athletes are
the games of the Baltimore Athletic Club,
which are to be held at the North Avenue
Skating Rink on January 28. Although we
have lost our coach, Mr. Mackdermott, there
is no cause for despair, for we have enough
well-trained athletes at the University to uphold our fame.
Captain Mullen, of the track team, has put
his team on training diet, and the men have
_been out in practice for several days. The
Hopkins team will probably consist of Garrett,
Simmons and Griffin in the weights; Fishach
and Simmons in the pole vault; Baetjer, Kerr
and Simmons in the jumps; Fitzgerald,

7

Knapp, Clark, Mullen, Riggs, De Grange,
Radcliffe, Morrison, Remsen and Frank in the
sprints. A number of Medical School men
will probably enter also.
The candidates for the track team are beginning to appear daily in the "cage," and Captain Mullen expects a large field from which to
make his final choice. All of last year's champion relay team are back at college, and it is
reported that there are many promising men
among the freshmen. It is to be hoped that
all students who have any athletic abilities
whatsoever will endeavor to develop them.
Captain Robinson, of the Lacrosse team, has
issued a call for all candidates to appear daily
in the "cage" in the afternoon. It is especially
desirable that new men should turn out early
in order to gain the much needed stick work,
lack of which is always an obstacle to effective
lacrosse playing. The old attack is back, and
will, no doubt, be even better than last year.
The defense, which must be made up of practically new men, is an object of care and
anxiety to the coaches.
HELIOTROPE.

Every sunbeam when it dies,
Leaves a dewdrop 'mongst the roses;
Every song an echo hides
In the silence, when it closes;
And my love a promise left me
When the sweet, sweet day was over—
'Tis this bit of Heliotrope
Hid within an old book's cover!
just a common piece of glass,
Mirrors back the sunbeam's motion;
Just a 1 ittle empty shell
Holds the echoes of an ocean;
But for me a charm still smaller
Holds the light and song of ages—
Just a bit of Heliotrope
Pressed between an old book's pages!
—John Erskine in "Morningside."

THE NEWS-LETTER.
UNIVERSITY NEWS.

Harris was the caterer. The dance was a very
enjoyable affair.

Invitations have been issued for the second
concert of the Musical Association, to be given
Saturday, the 14th, at 8.15 P. M.

On January 8 a deputation from Hopkins
Y. M. C .A., consisting of Messrs. Joseph
Akerman, H. T. Perkins and John C. French,
visited the associations at St. John's College
and the Naval Academy at Annapolis, and
made addresses on Y. M.C. A. work. On January 15, Dr. Steiner and W. L. Ross will represent Hopkins at Washington College.

A series of interesting lectures on "Dutch
and Flemish Art," by Professor Kuno
Francke, of Yale, is now in progress. The lectures are illustrated.
The musical clubs will probably give concerts in Bryn Mawr, Wilmington and Washington on their Easter trip.
The men who will try for the senior and
junior debating teams have given their
names to Dr. Lee, and are now preparing for
a special course in debate under his direction.
The contest this year promises to be close and
interesting.
Faculty and students were in evident attendance at the Peabody recital the afternoon of
the sixth instant, when Mrs. Fannie Bloomfield-Zeisler, Professor Bloomfield's sister, and
probably the world's most accomplished
pianiste, rendered a programme remarkable
for its scope and brilliancy of execution. The
unusually large audience was most enthusiastic in its appreciation, which Mrs. Zeisler acknowledged with several encores.
The first of the series of five Hopkins dances
to be given in McCoy Hall, took place Friday evening, December the 23d. The chaperones were Mrs. Daniel C. Gilman, Mrs. Edward H. Griffin, Mrs. Ira Remsen, Mrs. William T. Dixon, Mrs. Edward B. Bruce, Mrs.
Bernard N. Baker, Mrs. William Reynolds,
Mrs. William Whitridge, Mrs. E. Sinclair
Beale, and Mrs. C. Morton Stewart. An orchestra of ten pieces furnishr:d music, and

The twenty-third annual report of the President of the University to the Board of Trustees appeared a few clays ago. The first and
most important item is a complete account of
the granting of state aid by the legislature.
The usual statistics and reports follow. These
show a decided increase in the number of students over the report of last year, the growth
being mainly in the Medical School. It is interesting to note that this department of the
University, though the youngest, includes the
greatest number of students. As was the case
in '96-97 German was the most popular subject
and Biology a close second.
EXCHANGES.

The chess clubs of Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Columbia have sent a joint challenge
to Cambridge and Oxford for a chess match
by cable.
Columbia has a "Students' Employment
Committee," which registers the names of
students who wish employment of any kind,
and seeks to find work for them.
Training for the annual Brown-Dartmouth
debate is in full swing at the two colleges.
Williams College is to have a very attractive
new Y. M.C. A. building, which is expected to
prove a common link to the diverse college
interests and to broaden the college spirit.

CLASSICAL ARCHAEOLOGY.

In response to the request of the editors to
tell in the NEWS-LETTER something of the nature and scope of classical archaeology, I shall
attempt to state what classical archaeology is
and to define its place in the educational system. I must confess that to the general reader
archaeology sounds far away and mysterious,
altogether out of touch with modern life and
thought, but I hope to show that it belongs to
a branch of culture which we cannot afford to
neglect, and that the present vigorous prosecution of archaeological studies is a response
to the scientific spirit of the age.
In his memorable inaugural address, after
discussing the intellectual education and moral
education which the system of schools and
universities is intended to promote, John
Stuart Mill continues: "These are the two
main ingredients of human culture; but they
do not exhaust the whole of it. There is a
third division, which, if subordinate and owing
allegiance to the two others, is barely inferior
to them, and not less useful to the completeness of the human being; I mean the aesthetic
branch; the culture which comes through
poetry and art, and may be described as the
education of the feelings and the cultivation of
the beautiful."
Mill then emphasizes the place which
aesthetic culture occupies in any system of education which claims to be liberal, and shows
how the natural results of the study of the
fine arts are refinement of the taste, enlargement of the sympathies, cultivation of the
imagination and promotion of the love of
beauty.
Now as archaeology employs itself chiefly
with the study of the fine arts of antiquity,
with architecture and sculpture and painting—
it contributes largely to the aesthetic culture

No. 7

which Mill deems essential to the completeness
of the human being.
Furthermore, scientific method has demanded that the study of the ancient languages
should be brought into close connection with
the life of the peoples that spoke them. This
has created a desire for facts as to their laws
and their customs, their beliefs and their cults.
For these facts no source is so trustworthy
as the works of contemporary art, which may
be regarded as the mirror in which antique
thought is reflected. Hence the material relics
of antiquity—temples, and sculptures and
vases, the products of excavations at Athens
and Olympia and Delphi are now closely
woven into the web of classical learning. And
the science which treats this material and
makes information concerning it accessible to
every student of Greek and Roman literature
is classical archaeology.
We are now prepared to show the relation
of archaeology to classical philology, and to
define its province and departments. The reconstruction of the human past of Greece and
Rome is the grand ideal of classical philology
in its broadest sense. To accomplish this end,
it must collect, classify, and interpret the manifold record of antiquity. This record has come
down to us in the spoken language where that
is preserved, in the works of literature, and in
the monuments, i. e., in the extant remains of
architecture, sculpture and the other arts—in
fine, in all the results of human activity manifested in form and substance, as opposed to
the unsubstantial means employed in literature. This last branch comprises the subject
matter of classical archaeology and we may
define it as the scientific study of the monuments of classical antiquity which operate
through mass, form and color, according to
their peculiar modes of expression; or to put it

We present as our leading article in this
issue a brief discussion of Classical Archaeology by Dr. Mitchell Carroll. Dr. Carroll, who
was for some time a member of the American
School at Athens and derives his knowledge
of the subject at first hand, is now delivering
courses of lectures on "Greek Sculpture" and
"Antique Aesthetics." Courses on "The
Acroplis" and "The Topography of Athens"
were completed before Christmas. In this
connection many will remember the very entertaining lecture "Home Life in Pompeii,"
given last year by Professor Morgan, of Harvard. Such discussions show that archaeology
in spite of its scientific name, is a very interesting subject.
Some time ago favorable comment was
made in our columns on a proposal to revive
the dances formerly in vogue under the management of the Matriculate Society. Recently
it was announced that a series of dances had
been arranged, and the natural impression was
that they were of this character. Far from reviving the old dances, however, those now in
progress are on a plan entirely new at Hopkins. In the first place they are conducted by
a self-conStituted board of managers, and
though styled "Hopkins dances," are restrict-

ed to a limited number, whom the managers
choose to invite. In the second place, it appears that this prerogative, apparently derived
irom the authorities, has been used in an arbitrary manner. Acceptability in a certain circle
seems to be one requirement, affiliation with
certain fraternities another. The status of the
dances is thus left uncertain. The presence of
a member of the faculty on the board of managers adds to the official character implied by
the name and place. At the same time it is
privately declared that the dances are by no
means public affairs.
The result is general and well-justified
dissatisfaction among the students. The
action of the managers was unwise, and
the effect unfortunate. We question decidedly whether private dances have any
place in McCoy Hall, a building in which
we are supposed to have common rights. It
is certainly true that if such dances are held
they ought to be given by a definite organization and under a distinctive name. We can
hardly believe, however, that the authorities
contemplate granting the use of the hall for
exclusive dances given by various cliques of
students. Divisions enough exist already.
Hostility between fraternity factions and nonfraternity men has worked evil in our college
life before now, and one of the worst features
of the present affair is that it revives this feeling. When opposition of the two forces
brought about a dead-lock in the junior class
of last year, both sides recognized the harm of
it, and an amicable adjustment was reached.
Many hoped that this would continue. It
seems that the hope was vain. Perhaps still
more unfortunate, is the element of class distinction introduced by the managers.
There is no room for modern society
methods in our college life, and there is no
place where snobbishness is more undtsirable.
Opinions may differ as to the proportion of
"sheep and goats" among Hopkins students,
but we cannot feel that the undesirable element
includes a large majority of them. Certainly
if the latter class should presume to intrude in

THE NEWS-LETTER.
ATHLE,TICS.
IN-DOOR BASEBALL.

Last Saturday morning the inter-class indoor baseball schedule of games was resumed
in the cage, but the Christmas vacation has
not resulted, apparently, in any very great improvement in the playing of the teams. A beholder would not have been particularly edified at 'Saturday's game, except, possibly, in
regard to the superabundance of errors and
the wrangling over adverse decisions which
occupied the greater part of each inning. The
playing was by no means of the highest order,
except in a few cases, but the fact that the
teams did not have all of their regular men out
may have been partly responsible for this.
The indoor baseball season started in with
a loud flourish of trumpets, and the first few
games were marked by great enthusiasm and
fine team work. But the enthusiasm soon
waned, and the remaining games were postponed again and again, until they were in danger of sharing the fate common to too many
athletic enterprises at the University, which
begin their careers so brilliantly, only to glimmer and go out, and be forgotten.
The outdoor baseball season will soon be
upon us, and this indoor practice should develop material for the 'Varsity team. Our
baseball record for the past few years has not
been a particularly glorious one, and prospective candidates for this season's team should
take the utmost advantage of the opportunities
here offered. Do not let the indoor games end
in mere sport and amusement. Make them tell
in the way of practice.
Saturday's game between the Seniors and
the Freshmen resulted in a victory for the
former by a score of 9 to 5, although the
Freshmen improved toward the last and made
all their runs in the last three innings, while
the Seniors made theirs at the beginning of the
game. Downs pitched well for '99, and for
several innings he, with the assistance of the

first and third basemen, did all the work. 'Joyner made some wonderful catches at third,
stopping everything that came his way. Constantine, for the Freshmen, rivaled him in his
brilliant work at third, and was several times
applauded for his fine plays. Grimes, Hanna,
Guggenheimer, Swindell, Miller, and Briscoe
all played well.
The Freshmen were shut out up to the
seventh inning, but took a spurt then, and
made all their runs in the next few innings.
The umpiring was not the finest ever seen at
the University, and this resulted in much dispute. The players were, Seniors: Mullen,
Grimes, Downs, Joyner, Jones, Hanna, Guggenheimer, and Ford; Freshmen: Constantine, Briscoe, Miller, Straus, Tyler, Swindell,
James, Boyer, and Bruton.

THE EXHIBITION.

From time to time intimations are given out
of the elaborate plans that are being made for
the spring gymnastic exhibition. Teams representing the undergraduate classes are to
strive for a cup given annually by the UniverMr. James L. McLane, who had so
sity.
much to do with giving us the cage, offers a
gold medal for the best all-round gymnast.
Mr. William S. Hilles, A. B. '89, will provide
another for the best wrestler. The winner of
the contest in club-swinging will receive a fine
pair of clubs from Mr. E. D. Loane. A medal
provided by Professor Adams will be given to
the freshman whose strength tests show the
greatest improvement during the year. More
prizes may be added to the list before the exhibition.
If the contest for class teams is to be a success, there must be sonic faithful work in the
gym., especially by the juniors and seniors.
Compulsory gymnastics have so far failed to
compel, at least the upper classmen. It remains to be seen what effect prizes and class
spirit will have.

THE NEWS—LETTER.
THE FEED.

The Feed for this year will be held in the
cage and gymnasium Thursday evening, January 12. The exercises will be similar to those
of last year. There will be addresses by President Gilman, Professor Remsen, and Mr. William Hilles. The stunt games in the cage will
include several new features and some old
ones that have proved amusing. There will be
a greased pole to climb, sack and obstruction
races, "chicken-fights," boxing with blackened
gloves, and other things of like nature. Refreshments, the feature from which the function derived its name will follow. Mr. Robert
H. Grimes will be master of ceremonies and
Mr. William H. Mackdermott, clerk of the
course. Plans for the evening have been made
by a general committee, of which Mr. Grimes
is chairman and Mr. George W. Knapp, Jr.,
treasurer. The invitation to attend includes all
members of the University from "sub-fresh"
to faculty and all should be present.
THE B. A. C. (JAMES.

The lethargy in athletics, resulting from the
occupation of everyone's mind with examinations and the sterner things of life, is now at an
end, and steps are being taken toward the resumption of sports at the University.
The next event of interest to our athletes are
the games of the Baltimore Athletic Club,
which are to be held at the North Avenue
Skating Rink on January 28. Although we
have lost our coach, Mr. Mackdermott, there
is no cause for despair, for we have enough
well-trained athletes at the University to uphold our fame.
Captain Mullen, of the track team, has put
his team on training diet, and the men have
_been out in practice for several days. The
Hopkins team will probably consist of Garrett,
Simmons and Griffin in the weights; Fishach
and Simmons in the pole vault; Baetjer, Kerr
and Simmons in the jumps; Fitzgerald,

7

Knapp, Clark, Mullen, Riggs, De Grange,
Radcliffe, Morrison, Remsen and Frank in the
sprints. A number of Medical School men
will probably enter also.
The candidates for the track team are beginning to appear daily in the "cage," and Captain Mullen expects a large field from which to
make his final choice. All of last year's champion relay team are back at college, and it is
reported that there are many promising men
among the freshmen. It is to be hoped that
all students who have any athletic abilities
whatsoever will endeavor to develop them.
Captain Robinson, of the Lacrosse team, has
issued a call for all candidates to appear daily
in the "cage" in the afternoon. It is especially
desirable that new men should turn out early
in order to gain the much needed stick work,
lack of which is always an obstacle to effective
lacrosse playing. The old attack is back, and
will, no doubt, be even better than last year.
The defense, which must be made up of practically new men, is an object of care and
anxiety to the coaches.
HELIOTROPE.

Every sunbeam when it dies,
Leaves a dewdrop 'mongst the roses;
Every song an echo hides
In the silence, when it closes;
And my love a promise left me
When the sweet, sweet day was over—
'Tis this bit of Heliotrope
Hid within an old book's cover!
just a common piece of glass,
Mirrors back the sunbeam's motion;
Just a 1 ittle empty shell
Holds the echoes of an ocean;
But for me a charm still smaller
Holds the light and song of ages—
Just a bit of Heliotrope
Pressed between an old book's pages!
—John Erskine in "Morningside."

UNIVERSITY NEWS.

Harris was the caterer. The dance was a very
enjoyable affair.

Invitations have been issued for the second
concert of the Musical Association, to be given
Saturday, the 14th, at 8.15 P. M.

On January 8 a deputation from Hopkins
Y. M. C .A., consisting of Messrs. Joseph
Akerman, H. T. Perkins and John C. French,
visited the associations at St. John's College
and the Naval Academy at Annapolis, and
made addresses on Y. M.C. A. work. On January 15, Dr. Steiner and W. L. Ross will represent Hopkins at Washington College.

A series of interesting lectures on "Dutch
and Flemish Art," by Professor Kuno
Francke, of Yale, is now in progress. The lectures are illustrated.
The musical clubs will probably give concerts in Bryn Mawr, Wilmington and Washington on their Easter trip.
The men who will try for the senior and
junior debating teams have given their
names to Dr. Lee, and are now preparing for
a special course in debate under his direction.
The contest this year promises to be close and
interesting.
Faculty and students were in evident attendance at the Peabody recital the afternoon of
the sixth instant, when Mrs. Fannie Bloomfield-Zeisler, Professor Bloomfield's sister, and
probably the world's most accomplished
pianiste, rendered a programme remarkable
for its scope and brilliancy of execution. The
unusually large audience was most enthusiastic in its appreciation, which Mrs. Zeisler acknowledged with several encores.
The first of the series of five Hopkins dances
to be given in McCoy Hall, took place Friday evening, December the 23d. The chaperones were Mrs. Daniel C. Gilman, Mrs. Edward H. Griffin, Mrs. Ira Remsen, Mrs. William T. Dixon, Mrs. Edward B. Bruce, Mrs.
Bernard N. Baker, Mrs. William Reynolds,
Mrs. William Whitridge, Mrs. E. Sinclair
Beale, and Mrs. C. Morton Stewart. An orchestra of ten pieces furnishr:d music, and

The twenty-third annual report of the President of the University to the Board of Trustees appeared a few clays ago. The first and
most important item is a complete account of
the granting of state aid by the legislature.
The usual statistics and reports follow. These
show a decided increase in the number of students over the report of last year, the growth
being mainly in the Medical School. It is interesting to note that this department of the
University, though the youngest, includes the
greatest number of students. As was the case
in '96-97 German was the most popular subject
and Biology a close second.
EXCHANGES.

The chess clubs of Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Columbia have sent a joint challenge
to Cambridge and Oxford for a chess match
by cable.
Columbia has a "Students' Employment
Committee," which registers the names of
students who wish employment of any kind,
and seeks to find work for them.
Training for the annual Brown-Dartmouth
debate is in full swing at the two colleges.
Williams College is to have a very attractive
new Y. M.C. A. building, which is expected to
prove a common link to the diverse college
interests and to broaden the college spirit.
